Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

I hope JT has a sense of humour.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

2. Something will bite Trump in the ass and result in something hurting the US on an international level, and result in fallout on the international level. Take your pick what this is? Comment: "Lies, damned lies, and statistics" is a phrase describing the persuasive power of numbers, particularly the use of statistics to bolster weak arguments. It is also sometimes colloquially used to doubt statistics used to prove an opponent's point. Wikipedia Reference to Mark Twain's dubious attribution of this to Benjamin Disraeli.

I read the research mentioned and I would cite the following:
-The sample size in this study allows the authors to come to the conclusion they want to come to in the first place
-Oregon Live has an article on the worst Oregon wildfires, http://www.oregonlive.com/wildfires/index.ssf/2017/09/the_worst_wildfires_in_oregon.html
-Of these, half are brush fires
-The others are forest fires. All were in old growth or reburns of previous fires that did not get salvaged
-The Elliot Forest, became state ownership after the original old growth was burnt around 1880.
-The B&B Complex, Whitewater Fire, Eagle Creek, Strawberry Wilderness, all unmanaged lands

Comment: People have been prophesying that Vancouver is on the verge of a major crash since at least 2004. They figured that the 4-year run up in prices back then was about all that the market was good for. Who would pay more than $500k for a house in Vancouver? Or at least that's what they were saying at the time.

The point is that you can analyze to death the rent vs buy dilemma with the most hardcore spreadsheet that you can come up with - but you still can't predict the future.  Therefore, the result of this effort may be useful in that it can help you understand what *could* happen under various scenarios, but as for basing your decision solely on the financial analysis, it has limited usefulness. Instead, it should come down to what you value more. It might be owning a piece of property that you can work on and customize while having peace of mind knowing that no one can kick you out, or it could be the flexibility and reduced commitment of renting. Different strokes for different folks.

Comment: Development in poor countries is a priority that can contribute to the total global environmental improvement. Development will reduce population growth and harmful practices like slash and burn agriculture.
Why do you think that these places have not built with coal which has been around for over a century?  I spent a couple of years in very poor countries and coal is not a good solution.  The initial capital cost of a plant and infrastructure to get power to remote locations is large and then there are continuing fuel costs and maintenance. I live in a large town that had a diesel generator but that was unreliable and impossible to get to more remote locations. Coal would be worse.
Solar panels in minigrids with storage are being used to develop these areas.  The use of low current, low voltage devices like LEDs and solid state electronic means that not a lot of power is needed. I have seen refrigerators that can maintain 4 degrees C for a week using thermal mass/phase change.

Comment: Money invested passively inside a small business corporation for the purpose of saving to invest further in the company should not be taxed any higher than it is now. The problem is that few of these small business corporations use passive investment for these purposes. Most of them, especially high income professionals just use them to defer income until they are in a lower tax bracket when they are working less or are retired. Income splitting with a spouse and adult children not involved is just not defensible. Again, the abusers have not been the small business corporations with active involvement by family members (that's easy - just pay active family members a salary reasonable for what they do). No, again many of the abusers have been the high income professionals whose family members are not involved in the business at all who just want to lighten their tax burden. I was replying to this false statement by Susan.Hoyt3: 

"Resistance is not permissible when the occupation is the result of the aggression by those now occupied."

As a general statement about the laws of war, humanitarian .law, and international law, that's 100% false. Citizens of an occupied land may always lawfully take up arms to repel an invader. This was true before the United Nations was created, and it's even more so since. Under UN Treaty the onus is always on the occupying force to withdraw from lands outside its borders, unless it is duly authorized to remain there by order of the UN Security Council. And even if it is authorized to be there that in no way denies citizens the right to resist through armed force, as long as they do so in accordance with the laws of war.

Far from being authorized to occupy Palestine, the UN has repeatedly ordered Israel to withdraw.

Comment: I certainly DO KNOW what Jansenism is.  It is the Catholic version of Calvinism---an almost Puritanical version of Catholicism.  And I am well aware of its tenants.  In fact, a lot of Jansenism crept into the Catholic Church in America

Jansenist spirituality was an attempt to control the human passions through self-denial, mortification and asceticism.  This was essential to Jansenists because they feared that if they could not demonstrate control of the passions, they had not really been chosen by God for salvation after all.  A person predestined to salvation, it was thought, will act in a certain way.  

Many priests and nuns coming from Ireland in the late 19th and early 20th centuries were trained in the French theology and spirituality method [of Jansenism].  Too many Catholics were taught to be a suffering people, estimating how many days their aches and pains would get them out of Purgatory.  The joy and love of a savior who loves us was missing.

Comment: Richard, did you read the article? I know you've never taken a carbon sample but this article specifically mentioned the term aragonite dissolution. 

pH is just one parameter that is studied in chemical oceanography, it's part of the calculation that goes into saturation state. A good example is when you dump sugar into water and at one point the solution becomes saturated and won't dissolve anymore sugar. Who cares what the pH is if your saturation state means you dissolve. 

That's what these guys are finding, more water which is corrosive to aragonite (a huge chunk of the base of the food web is made out of aragonite) over large parts of the Arctic Ocean and they're expanding rapidly. 

UH has a nice writeup of what saturation state is, I suggest you read it. 

http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/mguidry/Unnamed_Site_2/Chapter%205/Figures/Box3SeawaterSaturationState.pdf

I would suggest that, as the Body of Christ, the Church is, indeed hurting when so many are leaving.  The Church is composed of human beings. The Church is not a family with adults and young children.  The church is a collection of thinking adults.  
I don't see any charity at all in telling those who are leaving that they are absolutely wrong, that the institution is completely right, and that they are all damning themselves.....

Comment: There's a lot of misinformation going on here, both in the NDP's plan but even more so in these comments. One particular recurring theme is that the Liberals' Green Energy Act is somehow responsible for most of the increase in Ontario's electricity prices. 
In fact, the combined total of solar, wind and bio energy only accounts for about 12% of the total, about $20 out of the average electricity bill of $170 (see http://environmentaldefence.ca/2017/02/01/shining-light-true-costs-renewable-energy-ontario/ for more detail).
Renewables do not even represent a large chunk of the Global Adjustment charge, an element of the total bill which has seen a large increase in recent years. By far the largest part of that is due to nuclear power (cost overruns, refurbishments, etc) , followed by gas.
If you want to single out a culprit here, then nuclear would be a better option.

Comment: Thank you for a thoughtful response. Having no official theological expertise, I'll hazard the view that the Mainline churches implicitly accept the earliest councils,  but not the concept that conciliar views are sacrosanct. The triumph of the monarchical Papacy model within your own church has also put conciliarism in the shade and infallibility though rarely used has deeply wounded it.

 As to sola scriptura, it certainly once had great purchase even in the mainline churches, and remains the lodestar of faith. However, within the Mainline there are, in Lutheranism and Presbyterianism, confessional statements. Anglicans have scripture, tradition and reason, and the BCP. These adopt dogma long held within the church, and in the case of Luther a ringing defense of Real presence against Calvin and Zwingli who took a spiritual presence only view. Today, the evangelicals (an amorphous term) are closest to the sola scriptura model, and dismissive of fixed prayer and liturgy.

Comment: Believer:

As Sandia says, she (Jennifer) is NOT doing the "technical and fundamental analysis". She is going to lists that a computer provides where a screen has been run -- a screen that, perhaps, looked at the Relative Strength Index (RSI) of a number of stocks. My broker's on-line system allows me to check the RSI of stocks, as does Stockcharts.com (and likely others) -- looking for stocks with RSI values of 30 and below as well as RSI values of 70 and above. This, and other screens, are not definitive and the investor must judge the worthiness of a stock's RSI (in this example). Most people would not allow RSI to pick an investment. I see it as an aid in TIMING an investment -- you like the company but would you be buying it after a long run higher -- or lower?

Jennifer is not "picking" anything. She is generating ideas. YOU must validate their worthiness of attracting your investing dollars.

Comment: This bill will (or should) go nowhere - 
Some combination of Seaton’s “income tax with a PFD offset”, plus a minimum PFD per resident cash payout ($500? $750?), but again with a 3-5 year sunset. This might satisfy those wanting the poorest &rural families to feel more financial pain.
This would be a more equitable (less inequitable?) approach that would not devastate our  poorest families, would raise revenues from job-holding rural residents, and would raise revenues from non-residents benefiting from Alaska jobs.  What more could a 21st century Alaska Republican want in the way of others bearing the pain?
Perhaps, in the spirit of "we all sacrifice",  we could also cap PFD cash payments to 4 per family? I'd favor THAT one!
I’d see this as a better stopgap approach - as long as we used the 3-5 year pre-sunset period for a MAJOR PFD revamp, bringing it more in line with Norway & the “sovereign wealth” funds now providing resident and governance benefits in other oil producing nations.

Comment: ...censured,

I prefer the French system with voting by two stages: an open primary in each single member riding followed a couple of weeks later by a runoff between the top 2 candidates in those ridings where no candidate attained at least 50%. The voter at each stage casts a ballot similar in form to the ones we cast under our system.

For the voter, the only change if this became our system would be that they would vote on two occasions in most cases.

Adopting this system would combine the features you favour plus ensure that the successful candidate is the first or second choice of at least 50% of those that vote.  The downside is the cost and bother of voting on 2 dates in most occasions.

Comment: Automation of the mills and of logging itself is, as I pointed out, and as most economists agree, and as is plainly visible in the industry, a real fact. Those old mills won't come back any more than the big trees will come back on those lands dedicated solely to trees as a raw material for lumber and sheet goods. The remaining old growth has greater value as a carbon sink, as a source of reliable clean water, and especially in dollar terms, as a recreational opportunity. The collapse of homebuilding, always a lagging victim of recessions but in this case a watershed event, was the major break point. Even with a new housing boom, 75% of those jobs won't ever come back, and with the death of union representation, those high wages won't return, unless the unions return.

Comment: One of the crazy things about the MOA is the absurd patchwork of tax districts, each with their own tax rate, each with their own level of municipal service.  There is a reason there has been such high turnover in the CFO position with the city over the last 20 years or so.  

The following map gives you an idea of what I am talking about.  I think there is an additional 2 or 3 districts up Eagle River way, and a district surrounding Girdwood proper.  The district in question is 15 to the SE of the map, and they are not taxed locally for police.  Meanwhile, the other districts have NOT agreed to pay for police service in district 15.

http://www.muni.org/Departments/finance/treasury/PropTax/Documents/tax-district-map.pdf

I am not arguing that the city is right, just trying to help explain the city's position.

Comment: A rail-funding bill is going to pass out of the legislature and go to the governor to sign. The question is how  the funding decision will affect Oahu residents. If the GET surcharge is extended to pay for the construction, most residents won't notice a difference. Things will remain the same as they have been for the past 10 + years (the GET surcharge began January 1, 2007).

If Matthew Johnson gets his way, the city will have to cut programs and services and raise property taxes, as well as other taxes and fees, to pay for the balance of work. In that case, residents will definitely notice a difference, a difference in their pocketbooks and in the quality of services provided by the city. They will also notice that the solution is not fair. 

Property owners will bear the lion's share of the cost. And tourists and others on temporary stays will pay none. Lower income residents, who will likely use rail the most, will not contribute either. Let's hope the legislature realizes this.

Comment: A number of years ago I turned right from the left lane into a parking lot entrance. A police officer gave me a ticket for a supposed illegal turn. As I was on vacation, I went to the library and looked up the Highway Traffic Act of Ontario. It said the turn I had made could be done if it did not interfere with traffic in the right lane--it hadn't, so I asked for a trial. After the police officer gave his testimony, with which I agreed, I asked the officer my turn had interfered with any traffic in the curb lane. He said it hadn't. I then read out the section of the Act and the judge responded "Case dismissed."

Comment: We have permitting requirements about the how much of the lot can be paved for good reason: it contributes majorly to surface runoff!  

Illegal and unpermitted construction that fills up the lots is a big factor in the flooding events in the Ala Wai Watershed (not just the canal).  We want more of that water to stay in Makiki, Manoa and Palolo.  Restore wetlands (with native plants--the Army Corps is a big fan of non-natives grasses).  Double down on the investment by creating nature parks that the public, residents and tourists, will want to spend time at.  We are deprived of green space within the urban environment, and not everyone can go hike a ridge (many can't here).  Keep in mind that the first consideration is keeping peoples' homes safe.

Good urban planning fulfills an efficiency of uses.  These ideas I'm bandying are not cheap or easy, but they are worthwhile and can work with sustained effort and long-term commitment.  Many other cities have done these kinds of things.

Comment: Younglai writes “the unemployment rate has remained close to the level seen before the [so-called] Great Recession.” (The 1981-82 recession under Trudeau père was much worse than the 2008-09 recession.)  This isn’t really so. Between October 2006 and August 2008, the unemployment rate ranged between 5.8% and 6.1% except for three months when it was 6.2%; the unemployment rate has never been under 6.2% under Trudeau fils, and except for August and September, it has never been as low as 6.2%. Comment: But campaigns DON'T get that pot of money. That's the point. That money stays independent, and is spent independently, even though it's spent to help or hurt a candidate, or a ballot measure, or an issue in general.

The money the campaigns get is already subject to pretty tight individual campaign contribution limits.  I suppose they could lower those limits even further, but what does that really accomplish?  That just takes the little guy out of the equation. The big guys now give their money to independent SuperPACs which is legal as long as they're not actual campaigns.  

Other than perhaps tightening the rules on non-coordination with campaigns (which surely takes place behind the scenes), there's really no putting the genie back in the bottle for independent spending. As government has grown bigger and more powerful, there's more incentive to influence it. The only way to reverse that is to shrink the size and scope of government (i.e. reduce the incentive to control it).

Comment: My grandfather, a Holmes Gold Medallist and Chief of Surgery at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Montreal for 10 years (sought by people from all across Canada as 'the best'), never made much cash. 40% of his patients could pay, but most paid in goods - eggs, chickens, hams, labour. Between him and his brother, during the height of the Spanish Flu epidemic, he worked 24/7 through a Canadian winter, in a horse drawn sled, under a Buffalo robe. He rarely stopped. My father remembers going out in the middle of the night to change the horse, give my grandfather a sandwich and some tea, before he went on to the next farm, house, hamlet. His brother, who owned a General Store, provided free food to feed the wives and children of the starving farmers in his care. They paid for it out of their own pockets.

And yet, my grandfather lived in a 14 room mansion, drove Buicks, and at his death in 1929, the family had the equivalent of what would today be 5 million dollars. Not a bad life.

Comment: Thanks Rob.  After years of investing for growth, with some success, a couple of years ago I decided to stop measuring my investing success by the size of my portfolio and instead measure it by the amount of annual dividends I'm earning.  I was concerned last year and strongly considered selling out in September and waiting for the 'crash'.  Subsequent events have proven that would not have been wise, and as I now move towards retirement this spring I have a healthy dividend portfolio of mostly Canadian Dividend All-Stars paying me more than I'll require in annual income to fund that retirement.  No more watching the ups and downs of the market.  I'm following the annual dividend increases that I expect to take care of inflation in the coming years.  People need to re-access how they measure their investing success, and not worry so much about short term gains and losses in stock values.

Comment: My sales manager recommends leasing versus buying, for a number of reasons. In Ontario, an accident involving reportable damage immediately lowers the value of a vehicle, and  in the high end market, might make it simply unsaleable. He said he would not want to take it in as a trade-in, even if "we" fixed it, (he works for a dealer at Audi, M-B or BMW). 

The extent of rear end accidents is significant, given the poor driving habits, including aggressive behaviour, and so the chances of an owner taking a financial hit due to being hit are increasing by the day. Of the four drivers in our family, three have been hit from the rear, most notably when stopped at traffic lights. 

By contrast, a leased vehicle would need to be repaired, but at the end of the lease, the manufacturer takes the value hit.

Apparently in B.C. the law is different, while in Ont.the no fault legislation continues to allow poor drivers to escape from serious financial risk due to being sued by the people they hit.

Comment: When deciding whether statues of Robert E Lee and others who led - and championed - the Confederate cause deserve display in the most prominent locations in some US cities, context is indeed useful. 

Here is an account of a slave auction in Montgomery, AL by a Times of London reporter on May 5, 1861:

'The auctioneer...had his 'article' beside him...a stout young Negro, badly dressed and ill-shod, who stood with all his goods fastened in a small bundle in his hand, looking out at the small and listless gathering of men who had moved from the shady side of the street as they saw the man put up.

"A prime field hand! Just look at him - good natured, well tempered, no marks....only $950 for him! Why it's quite ridiculous! $950!"

The price rose to $1000...the auctioneer, the Negro, and his buyer...walked off to settle the transaction, and the crowd moved away.

"That n*gger went cheap", said one of them to a companion. "Yes sir, n*ggers is cheap now - that's a fact!" '

God have mercy.

Comment: The reporting on PERS is just abysmal. The right wing think tanks regularly feed prejudicial language to the press. "...worsening the retirement system’s already-dire long-term outlook." "Dire," really? "Avalanche?" See Bloomberg: www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2017-state-pension-funding-ratios/  Are retirement plans expensive? You betcha. And they always will be. If we didn't pay into retirements would we have more money to spend on safety, teachers, and parks? Of course, but that's true for all state budget items. Did court decisions "hamstring" efforts to cut PERS benefits? Only if "hamstring" means being free to cut benefits over 20 times since 1995 and to radically restructure the system twice. And is it the Court or the law that sets limits to unilateral retroactive reneging on contracts? Geez! And then giving the last word to business interests! The folks who who spend millions to protect their lowest-in-the-nation corporate tax burden and to sack the retirements of working folk.

Comment: Good for you, you will not be a drain on the system. It is too bad more people don't think this way. The more money I have it seems as though the less "stuff" I want. I have seen many studies that show that most retirees live on far less than 50K a year and seem to be happy. Usually their costs go down, no commute, no saving, no expensive clothes, fewer meals out...Of course the financial services industry continually uses 70% of your income as a figure because they want to make more in fees and commissions by having you invest more. Most people can maximize their returns simply by either holding a basket of conservative dividend paying stocks or a few index funds for the long term and slowly drawing them down upon retirement. No need to pay a financial advisor a percentage of your assets, as most rarely even match the performance of the index and the fees really eat into your returns. If you have to get a fee based plan, but that is all most people need.

Comment: Some 60 years ago, I sold newspapers on the streets of Anchorage and people of Anchorage relied heavily on the ADN and Times for information about our state and nation. I was raised to have a mind of my own, to ask questions when needed. Have an opinion and use use what the good lord put between my shoulders, to think with, but not be branded by these labels. 

My first job was selling papers for a person I greatly respected, Bob Atwood at the Anchorage Times and never once did I hear him use these labels.

I for one greatly appreciate the ADN for hanging in with our community and providing the news and our news!

Comment: Republicans failed because they didn't take the time to put something forward that was a real improvement. Just several slap-dash efforts of crafting a bill in a couple of weeks with no real review or discussion with patients, doctors, insurers, etc. And no thinking out of the box.

I read about an idea that I think has merit. Put your partisan blinders up (and I'm sure this idea has flaws all its own), but I think it's a good starting point: Single-payer for all with something like a $50K deductible (no one knows what the real number should be, so for right now $50K is a placeholder). The government covers you for all expenses above $50K. Below that, you are on your own. Pay out of pocket or find an insurance to cover you below $50K. Totally free market and unregulated, with premiums no worse than car insurance. If you don't get that insurance, you can't bankrupt out of your medical bills. In essence, it combines a lot of what Dems want and Repubs want. And unties it from employers.

Comment: Dear James,

I feel very bad for you.  How old are you? In your twenties?

If you were my son, I would give you a hug and tell you that you will get past this.  This is part of growing up.  And someday, after the anger dissipates and you have another job, you will realize how naïve and young you were. 

Someday, you will understand how this “manifesto” was a mistake.

It will seem like one of those tweets you wish you could get back or that email message that you wished you did not send.

Many people have already told you that your assumptions are based on bad data or bad science.  I don’t need to do that.  But that is not the point, is it?

Perhaps you will understand when you look down at your newborn daughter and hope that she is not held back by someone else’s idea of what she can be. 

In the meantime, the next time you have an urge to vent or try out an idea, get some feedback from your mom before you hit send.

Sincerely,

A mom

Comment: I think it is more accurate to say that picking Al Gore cost the Democratic Party the election in 2000.  

The Democratic Party chose HRC knowing that she was unpopular with large sections of the electorate, including their own supporters.  If you deliberately pick a candidate that you know your base dislikes, you can hardly blame them for voting for someone else.

I would add that if it really does to turns out to be as close as you fear, then a third-party candidate like Johnson would in fact be electable.   

Johnson's views fall somewhere between the two major parties, he has executive experience, and he is generally seen as honest and ethical.  If no candidate gets 270 votes (e.g. if it is close and Johnson picks up a State or two), then the House gets to pick between the top 3 candidates.  I think in such a situation, the House is much more likely to pick Johnson than either Clinton or Trump.

Comment: It works for auto insurance. In the 1980s, when it was under discussion, the argument was that Alaska (as an example) had such high costs for repairs and the winter conditions meant we used insurance so much more frequently that there could never be a private auto insurance where by private insurance companies were able to sell insurance across state lines. There was a huge furor about it and then it was opened up across state lines and the system works. Alaskans pay slightly more than the national average for, say, GEICO, and get comparable service based upon Alaska's reimbursement laws and the statistics for the state and ... viola ... everybody is covered at an affordable rate.

Those who refuse to learn from history ....

Comment: If you need more $ for infrastructure, cut waste across the fed. gov.!  But as to the math...  If a project is NOT a good investment, and does not attract private capital to build and operate it, then it is still NOT a good project, with public $$.  One would think this would be obvious, but JT is JT.  One reality in public procurement is that contractors know that the public is the final payor, so delays and cost overruns are very common and very large (see defense spending!!).  Injecting a profit motive, therefore, CAN in principle force efficiency, as a build/operate firm has real incentives to control costs.  Against that there is the fact they expect to make a decent return, much more than the % cost of debt to the government.  But even if you like some private involvement, you don't need this bank - just let private capital build Edm/Cal if it pays, if not, too bad!  This is just a badly disguised subsidy scheme, to get $ into dumb showcase projects, or the friends of Junior.

Comment: I see a number of people asking whether a gun can be drawn and employed if the perp is just a few feet away with a knife. Just a couple of quick comments... 

1.  Separate! Move, step aside and/or back, get yourself out of the perp's immediate reach.
2.  While moving, draw your weapon. Do not "show it to him", do not issue a warning... put the front sight on the center of mass and pull the trigger.  Repeat as necessary.  If the perp is too close to use the sights, don't worry...  at 6 feet, you won't need them anyway. Instinctive pointing works well at that range... 

Remember, the element of surprise works both ways. Typically, a thug with a knife won't be expecting you to be carrying a gun... if he did, he probably would not have chosen you as his target. He will be surprised to see the gun in your hand, and it will take him a second or two to process that... enough time for you to score a couple of solid hits, if you've trained as you should for concealed carry.

Comment: According to StatsCan, the cohort of immigrants who first filed taxes in 2004 had a median income of $16,600. By 2014, the median for that same group was $33,000. You can't buy any sort of property in these regions on $33,000/yr.

Perhaps Doug is referring only to the 50% of more recent immigrant households that have one or two university-degreed breadwinners. That would mean less than 25% of recent immigrants. I wonder how many of these folks had money from outside Canada to help them purchase? And, what's happening with the other 75%?

In the 1960s, the % of home ownership among immigrants was higher than for non-immigrants. That % has declined steadily since, and increasingly, most immigrants require more years in Canada to reach ownership, if they attain it at all.

Comment: The context here is a difficult one. Part of it is historical. I can see how it's important to get clear about the history of PERS and the reforms that have been made, but I can't see what part of that history helps us to solve the problems we face now. Part of that context is also the history of political incompetence in Oregon government that carved up higher ed in a disastrous way and left the UO with a permanently dysfunctional revenue structure. Again, though, the question is what to do now. The context is also a larger one for Oregon itself. Our government, our schools, our infrastructure, our tax structure, and our system of higher ed are all antiquated. They need to be modernized. The UO is trying to remake itself in a bold way but a way that is necessary if it is to have a real future. Oregon faces the same challenge. The real issue is whether we are going to pay our bills and invest in our future by modernizing and improving Oregon itself. The issue before us is Measure 97.

Comment: "...2015, when the exchange rate was still ok"

Right there you show you don't know anything. The exchange rate being "OK" ie. the 1 CAD was closer to 1 USD would not be an advantage to a physician returning to Canada. It would be a disadvantage.

With the Canadian dollar lower now it is more to the advantage of someone in the US selling their assets - home etc. - and moving to Canada. Those US assets are worth more compared to the Canadian equivalent now that the dollar has fallen. Income from US investments are worth more now when converted to Canadian dollars than if the Canadian $ was closer to par.

Similarly, selling your Canadian house, etc. and taking those Canadian dollars to the US costs you more now. Now that the CAD has fallen moving to the US is a more expensive proposition. And once you're there with both your income and expenses in US$ it no longer matters one way or the other what the exchange rate is.

Comment: Who do you think pays for the roads now? Both federal and provincial fuel taxes account for up to $0.45 per litre in the region.  Folks on transit do not pay these taxes that support the roads AND transit. And, when 3/4 of the mode share in the region is by car or truck, some 610,000 vehicles during the morning rush period, I would think these folks are paying for the roads.  As well, since 3/4 of the ride share is by a vehicle other than transit, the hydro levy and property tax surcharge are also paying the lion's share of transit's operating and debt service costs.  Currently 1/3 of Translink's revenue comes from fares the other 2/3 comes from fuel taxes, hydro levy and property tax surcharge.  When Translink boasts of an increase in transit mode share they do not tell you its because more than 150,000 students are provided a substantial fare discount which can be used 24 hours a day (U-Pass).  Students pay almost $40 a month while non students must pay $170 a month.

Comment: "Trudeau isn't doing so poorly"

There's lots of angles to attack this one, but one example will suffice: marijuana legalization.  

The LPC 'legalized marijuana' by downloading the responsibility for enforcement, policy and standards to the provinces, but nonsensically retained federal criminal legislation for sale to minors, introducing a guaranteed conflict between the provincial right to set age of majority and federal enforcement of that law.  Are we really going to get into the business of arresting people and putting them in FEDERAL prison for selling to an 18 year old in Ontario, when that 18 year old can cross over into Quebec and buy it perfectly legally?  It's what already happens with alcohol, but we're talking fines at the provincial level for alcohol, not felony convictions like we would with pot.

It's juvenile legislation that got rushed so the feds had a chance of getting it out in the public's eyes by 420. It's that kind of 'optics first' thinking that's so idiotic.

Comment: As a freelancer, I was forced a couple of years ago to incorporate in order to get work in my field as a contractor  through recruitment agencies (and sometimes through direct interaction with the employer). 

 In the past I'd done this kind of work as a sole proprietor, paid my rate of tax less whatever my expenses were.  Due to a couple of lawsuits where some sole proprietors doing contractual work sued the companies they were working for not providing EI opportunities etc. (they found some loopholes), most recruiting agencies and many companies are now reluctant to hire professional contractors unless they're incorporated.  These sole proprietors missed the point of 'freelance', and so ruined it for the rest of us.

I'll bet the number of incorporations have shot up in the past few years.  This is one reason why.  This article and others (not to mention the government) paints everything with the same brush, but small businesses and their origins are wildly diverse.

Comment: This "incident" is so bizarre that it is unreal.
Two professional pilots (in the Air Canada plane), in clear weather conditions, lined up to land on a taxiway (taxiways have blue sideline lights, runways have white sideline lights) with 4 aircraft on it.
The explanation for this one will go far beyond the old saw, "pilot error". One person can make a mistake if they're tired, incapacitated, distracted, whatever. When two people, who have been thoroughly trained in what is called "crew resource management" (in other words, never letting the other guy make a critical error that goes uncorrected) make the same mistake, at the same time, the question "why?" is overwhelming.
Set aside every other factor and what anyone else should have done, it is the pilot's job to safely manoeuvre his aircraft regardless of what anyone else tells him. If he saw other aircraft on what he thought was his runway, he should have initiated the overshoot himself, regardless of what the controller said.

Comment: Pipelines and utilities (continued)...
As the author pointed out, a bond investor might not be able to handle the volatility of equities in general. At least historically, and one can go back much further in time than this ~ 14 year study, an investment in these two areas has been much less volatile than the overall market's volatility (look at both best and worst years), has provided investors with much less risk of loss of capital (see both losing periods and largest decline) and got them back to a new high in the value of their portfolio in a far shorter period of time (see time to breakeven.)
This approach will not be for everyone. But for me at least, the odds of achieving above returns while at the same time taking below average risk over the long term (decades) are without doubt in my favour. And decidedly better than owning bonds.

 Japan & Taiwan each claim an island with an airstrip even though they are 2000 miles away.
Phillipines, Malaysia & Brunei all claim their fair share.

The Americans have 3 Aircraft Carriers and at least a dozen Destroyers in the region, and were there long before China started building.

Comment: Wonderful article. I had the life changing experience of living in McGrath and learning from natives how to hunt, gather berries and wood, and what it meansto live in a community. An elder also came to the kill site to gether favorite parts including the tongue, liver, caul fat, kidneys and everything else she was able to use. Hunting is part of rural life that many who have not lived there will not understand. 
Your story was beautifully written and brought me back to 2010 when McGrath was my home.

Comment: Thanks for the article, Scott. Very interesting.

Do use portfolio metrics such as Sharpe ratios to measure a portfolio’s risk-adjusted returns? 

I first got into investing in the mid 1990s with low-cost mutual funds as ETFs were then rare. I came across a useful software called PakTrak developed by a finance prof in Ontario that would provide a risk-return profile of a portfolio of mutual funds. I then had a relatively low-risk portfolio with returns somewhat above the TSX at a fraction of its volatility.

I think PalTrak is still around, now owed by Morningstar and oriented towards investment advisors. 

But I have not seen anything comparable that could do such estimates for a portfolio of individual stocks. Have you?

Comment: To suggest that TWU as a 'private institution' is free to discriminate contrary to protected human rights is absurd. Were that the case any private institution offering services to the public, accepting government funding, employing staff, etc. could discriminate against anyone based on race, religion, nationality, colour, etc. If they can ignore human rights laws, then it follows that, regardless of the reasons, they could freely ignore any other laws such as employment standards. health and safety act, environmental laws... why not the criminal code? Obviously, they can't. Your argument doesn't hold water in the face of reality. 

Furthermore, nobody is suggesting that institutions don't have rights - clearly they do. But rights, religious rights included, are limited - not absolute. Institutions operating in the public domain (as TWU does) are not entitled to discriminate against individuals in defiance of human rights legislation. Indeed, the Supreme Court of Canada says so.

Which is essential because the nonprofits running the rest stops can't afford to buy or lease land. The city claims it hasn't been able to find any place to put the Nightingale rest stop, or any new ones. What they really mean by that is they can't find any sites that comply with the ordinance that are politically acceptable. If you know different, you need to tell the City Manager and City Council.

Comment: Okay. I see where you're coming from. I strongly disagree with you about God's number one concern. If that is your view, well then, of course freedom and charity don't matter all that much. 

I take more of a Maxwellian view that God's number one concern is that we love and trust Him. The story of the Fall tells me that it is our refusal to love, trust and obey Him that leads to pain and suffering. And if God decided to insulate us in this life from the existential consequences of our refusals to love and trust Him, that would infringe on freedom. Kingdom living is all about demonstrating our love and trust through self-sacrificing charity. Important as the law is, it does not produce Kingdom living or the fruits of the Spirit - a reality that St. Paul profoundly ariticulated. 

I am not against social justice advocacy  - i.e., legally mandated morality. It's fine for Christians, as citizens, to fight for what they believe are just laws. But that's not the role of the church.

Comment: I would really like EPA to help set up a demonstration project for a full-service recycling center that processes all solid waste for re-use or re-sale. Comment: The grid is designed to minimize damage from lightning strikes and faults (like high voltage wires falling on lower, wires being shorted to earth, etc.).

To protect against lightning strikes traveling on the conductors their are lightening arrestors distributed all over the grid.
Some operate by shunting the voltage to ground.
Others by forcing it to create an arc that dissipates the temporary voltage on the line.

Both devices work fast enough to protect the grid itself.
Grid equipment is not easily damaged.
The arrestors have been designed to limit excess voltage so that it Does NOT damage grid components.
Current takes time to heat up and cause damage.
This very heating allows fuses (intentional 'weak' spots) to melt and open.
Circuit breakers in the distribution system are normally magnetic.
Higher current creates a magnetic field that opens the breaker contacts.
They also are designed to limit the tine current passed to prevent other damage.

Comment: Way back when the US formed it was always imagined the new union would include the Canadian colonies, even (especially) Quebec. The absence of Canada from the US union was an entirely manageable affair for the two hundred year existence of the United States, even though our absence essentially put the US into imbalance, possibly  one reason the north/south US split became so intransigent so quickly. For two hundred years, we have been an ally and cultural cousin of our neighbours to the south. But increasingly, our absence means bad outcomes for the US and the world.  Canada and the US should become one political entity, possibly with Quebec in a Schengen-like arrangement, and restoring North America as one political space as it had been for centuries. Why vote at the margins, when our votes could tip the US balance of power, and in doing so, shape the world. That's how the world gets more Canada, through a more Canadian America. Union, hope and a more peaceful world.

Pat,
First, and foremost, please accept my unreserved condolences for your loss.  I will not pretend to know what you suffered and I pray that she is now in that place for which our souls longs.

Comment: addendum.... Bill Clinton was impeached, which by definition means he was accused of wrong doing. Remember, in the US, the House of Representatives determines if the President should be put on trial. Wild creatures don't have many choices what to eat.  Fortunately we "civilized" humans do.

When Susan hurts one creature in the great Web Of Life, she hurts us all.

Comment: Relevant to John Bond's comments is something that hasn't received wide attention despite having been known for decades:  Communication towers kill up to 7 million birds/year in the US.  Generally, the taller the tower, the worse the problem.  Here's a link:

http://www.livescience.com/19908-migratory-birds-killed-towers.html

The photo shows an Omega tower, very similar to Lualualei's VHF towers used for communication with subs.  Those towers were, when built (1972), the highest in the Western Hemisphere.  I wonder if bird and bat kill statistics are available for these military towers.

Recent studies have shown that bird kills are greatly reduced when blinking lights replace the steady lights commonly used in the past.  This finding is now being applied to wind turbines.  I suspect sonic devices will work better than optical devices when it comes to bats.

We must protect our endangered bats and birds, so research money should aim at steering them away from windmills and towers.

The issue is beginning to resemble how people choose to euthanize their pets.

Comment: This has already been discussed here: An anti-bark collar is not an electronic fence collar. And nothing in the article suggests either the electronic fence or the electronic collar was malfunctioning. If you read the article you will note that in 2015 his anti-bark collar had a dead battery, which lead to him barking at somebody and so the original complaint. 

That has nothing to do with an electronic fence collar in 2016. The collars that go with electronic fences normally are NOT anti-bark and for good reason -- you don't want the dog confused over whether he is getting shocked because he is close to the boundary or because he is barking. I know because I have both collars for my dogs and I need to choose which one they wear.

Yes indeed he was barking because he did not have his bark collar on. He had his electronic fence collar on. And if you shoot an animal running he will continue moving for a short period of time, hence why dog was half out of his yard.

Comment: Scientific opinion is all over the ballpark on that, Andrew. (But I'm guessing you already knew that!)

For instance, the AMS just did a survey of broadcast meteorologists, and asked that question. They're a good group of scientists to ask, because they are well-qualified to distinguish between climate change and mere weather, but most of them have no "skin in the game" to bias their opinions.

The AMS found that only 15% of those meteorologists now believe that more than 80% of the last fifty years' warming is due to human activity. Another 34% think 61-80% of the warming is due to human activity. That means 15+34=49% believe that more than 60% of the last fifty years' warming is due to human activity.

So, the "average position" is that a little over half of the warming was caused by man (mostly by CO2).

That's not enough to be worrisome. It suggests an ECS climate sensitivity of only 1.5 - 2.0 °C, and a TCR sensitivity of only about 1.0 °C.

Refs: http://sealevel.info/glossary.html

Comment: Mr. Palmer leaves out (possibly intently) some very important facts regarding vacations rentals. Vacation rentals are allowed and conforming in all resort zoning, but are non-conforming for residential zoning.  If someone want to operate a vacation rental, all they need to do is buy a property in resort zoning. Portions of Waikiki and Ko Olina are good examples of resort zoning that allow individuals to partake in the visitor lodging industry. The reason why vacation rentals are non-conforming for residential zoning is that they are not a compatible land-use for residential neighborhoods and they reduce our residential housing supply.  Currently, Oahu needs an additional 25,000 homes within the next 5-10 years to shelter local residents. If we follow Mr. Palmer's advice and convert between 11,000 to 17,000  (3-5%) of our residential-zoned homes into visitor lodging businesses, we're going to have a lot more residents go homeless. Frankly, Mr. Palmer's proposal makes "No Sense"!

Comment: It's a challenge to find wild beavers in the beaver state these days. Seems like industry's "farming" of the state's tree, Doug-fir, is threatened by hungry beavers and their dam building.

Beavers are not protected in Oregon. ORS 496 designates beavers as furbearers, which allow beavers to be hunted with no bag limits. ORS 610, considers beavers a “predatory animal”, similar to a U.S. Department of Agriculture lawnaming beaver a “varmint”. Predator” and “varmint” designations allow and encourage anywhere, anytime trapping or poisoning of our states animal.

Research confirms that when there were more beavers and beaver dam created backwaters, there were more salmon. Killing off Oregon's beaver is also helping to kill off our state fish, the Chinook salmon.

Oregon will be a poorer state once these iconic animals and fish are gone.

Comment: Very true, you got to PAY taxes into the Medicare system for 10 years to qualify for Medicare part A and be a RESIDENT in the US for at least 5 years.  If you don't PAY taxes for 10 years, you can PAY for that part A premiums dependant on how much years you worked and PAID into the system.

If you did sign up with a Medicare Advantage program, that one takes the place of paying for the bills of Medicare, but you are always in the Medicare system.  In that case Original Medicare will not pay anything as your Medicare Advantage plan will be the only one to pay the bill.  If you did have a Original Medicare and paid for a Medicare Supplement plan, then Medicare will be primary and Supplemental plan secondary.  Or in the case of State, Federal, (unless they have Kaiser as they get an MA plan), VA, Tricare retirees they also have original Medicare with a secondary coverage.  Again they are lucky to get retiree benefits, but again, they WORKED hard for those benefits.

Comment: Section 6 of the Statehood Act (the land-grant section) is a stand-alone Section; it is not modified by Sec. 5.  It dovetails with Sec., 5 which recognizes that the US will not retain title to land selected by the State under Art. 6.
 Your "Art. 12, Sec. 12" quote  is from the Alaska Constitution, not the Statehood Act.  The Constitution was adopted by the people of Alaska, and not imposed by the US government.  It simply says that Alaska and its people disclaim any claim of title to any land in Alaska not granted to it by Congress in the Statehood Act, to include any unresolved Native claims.  The disclaimer applies only to land within Alaska that is retained by the US, and to Native claims.
BTW -- I am a natural-resources  lawyer who has practiced federal and state land law exclusively in Alaska for 45 years.  I hope this mercifully puts you out of your misery.

Comment: America might not be "made great again" by ignoring the hard lessons learned.   Be very leery of this mantra to  "deregulate" where for every "new"  regulation two others must be rescinded.

 For example,   I used to prepare and document dangerous goods for transport by air. Some were limited to cargo aircraft only while others were allowed on passenger aircraft.  Some could not be shipped with other dangerous goods on the same aircraft.  Some were forbidden to transport by air under any circumstances (e.g. expired oxygen generators of the type which downed the Air Florida passenger aircraft).  Those particular regulations helped protect the public and I would not want to fly on any aircraft (cargo or passenger), if after some time 2/3 of those regulations were removed.

Comment: G2,  I'll take a stab at this strictly from my point of view. First, what everyone is calling "clips" should really be called magazines. If a bad "person" was trying to to load his/her weapon via clip, it would really, really slow them down if it was a modern civilian semi-automatic weapon such as the AR family (M4/M16).  But for the purists out there, an M1 Garand (think WWII and Korea) a clip would be correct but it only holds 8 rounds. Spend some time on your search engine of choice and you'll see what I mean.
I own two AR type carbines and lots of thirty round magazines. Seldom do I ever fill them to max capacity but when I do, I do. The main reason is I don't want to bother with reloading so often. There are times when I just want to keep up a sustained rate of fire. Mostly this occurs when I am teaching somebody specific shooting techniques and/or circumstances.
If you haven't, take a trip over to the Bear's Den and shoot their Thompson sub-machine gun on semi and full automatic.

Comment: You makes it sound like a 401K is a bad thing. If you're working for a company that doesn't invest it well, that's true, but the State of Alaska does a good job of investing the Tier 4 retirement funds and they grow at a good pace. Sure, compared to Tier 1, the Tier 4 worker has to put a lot more of their own money in, but we're legally assured the money will actually be there, whereas the Tier 1 system was never fully funded, so if the State goes bankrupt, Tier 1 retirees may find themselves with no pension.

Defined benefit plans always had this risk, but people weren't aware of it. Defined contribution plans are much more sustainable and, therefore, more likely to be available to the worker at retirement. Your employer can't tap a 401(k). The federal government can ... as they did in Italy and Cyprus to pay down government debt.

Comment: The AP uses the term "Muslim Majority countries" because the greatest percentage of citizens in the countries are Muslim. Your source is discussing not the percentages, but the absolute number of people in the world who are Muslim. For example, China has more Muslims than Syria although most people in China are not Muslims. See  http://www.pewforum.org/2009/10/07/mapping-the-global-muslim-population/ ,
I believe the AP term is still misleading because the seven countries in the original order were chosen during the Obama administration for enhanced security measures. It is unlikely the Obama administration selected the seven countries because they were majority Muslim countries. The new Executive Order ( https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/03/06/executive-order-protecting-nation-foreign-terrorist-entry-united-states ) provides the history of the countries being put on the list, including the Obama Administration's reasons for each individual country.

Comment: No, it doesn't. Note it applies in a "dwelling," not business or any other property. Note also that the law avoids making mere unlawful entry the sole criterion for use of deadly force, although in actual cases, that has pretty much been the case. You are not entitled to use deadly force to protect your property, except in a dwelling, and if a threat of physical force is likely, as this statute describes. A jury might find lesser uses of force to protect property outside a dwelling reasonable, or it might not, but using deadly force to protect property outside your dwelling is not sanctioned by any statute. Person, property are different. Dwelling, elsewhere are different, unless you live in Colorado Springs.

Comment: I disagree with your portrayal of Councilmember Dana Ralph. 

CM Berrios and Ralph agreed - we can't wait on parks, differing on how to pay. CM Ralph rightfully pointed out the un-sustainability of CM Berrios' one-time approach to fund much-needed and long-delayed work.

It is simply untrue that the B&O in the original ordinance was 100% for streets. Everyone seems to forget the compromise in 2012 when it was passed. Former CM's Perry and Albertson insisted on revenue over $5M/yr going to the Capital Resource fund. W/out compromise, the ordinance wouldn't have passed; the city wouldn't have re-paved Central Ave. and James St. among others.

The 2012 compromise got the Capital Resource fund debt under control, restored fund balances, and revived the city's bond rating. Every Kent resident and business benefits from this good fiscal management. These one-time funds wouldn't otherwise exist.

I was proud to second CM Ralph's amendment. It was the responsible, sustainable approach.

Comment: The requirement for rescue insurance might be a worthwhile discussion, however, the amount of money that is spent annually on SAR in the United States is far down the list of expenses that need mitigating, especially considering its function and purpose. The same account that pays for incidents such as this one pays for lost children in parks (when the incident meets the "major SAR" category, e.g. an extended search with multiple resources). Should anyone who requires any assistance be charged for rescue? Parents of lost children? It's also worth noting that many SAR resource personnel are volunteers, or otherwise are professional rescuers who chose that line of work for a reason. All I'm saying is that the outrage that happens every time there is an incident like this is quite misplaced. I might add that Masatoshi (the subject here) has been climbing solo in the Alaska Range in winter for the past 20 years. This was the first time he's been in trouble. That says a LOT about his skills

Comment: It is highly unlikely the US will impose a 20% tariff on oil. They would be shooting themselves in the foot. Electicity and gas are probably in the same boat.

No overseas oil exporters would absorb what amounts to a 20% discount on the price they receive. They will send their crude to other markets. That means refineries importing the stuff would have to absorb the tax or do without imported crude. 

Even if shale oil producers open the spigots wide they still cannot replace all the imports. In affect this would result in a rise in the price Americans pay for their gasoline and  an upward adjustment to the price of US domestic crude by as much as 20%.

Canada will initially have a problem with the tax but if US domestic oil prices rose by that much it would  balance out. Still some Canadian suppliers may be unable to sell into the US at a profit. Their oil will probably go to eastern Canada by train.

The author has not thought things out enough.

Comment: There are a lot more state and corporate regulations in place regarding teenage employment, than when I was a kid.  My 17 yr old son went looking for his first job this summer.  We have a bunch of new casual restaurants near us (Jimmy John's, Mod Pizza, Mad Greens), all advertising openings, yet only hire people 18 or older.  There are regulations that limit the scope of work a person under 18 can do at the store, so they don't want to hire them.

He ended up getting a job at Walmart, which also is required to limit certain tasks due to safety regulations.  Walmart is responsible for additional oversight for those under 18.

And don't fall for the low minimum wage argument.  Not many actually get paid the minimum wage.  My son is making over $11/hour at Walmart, for a first time job.

Comment: I'm grateful for the effort the legislators put into all of this year's sessions. They have addressed some monumental issues, all very difficult to resolve. These folks need some time to reflect and recalibrate. They also need to spend time in their communities to truly understand the people they represent. Those who return next year, including the Governor, should start with a renewed energy and a willingness to listen to each other, and co-create a future for Alaska. If the energy and willingness are not there, then they should step aside and make room for a new cadre of leaders in Juneau.

Comment: That's the motto, but that really isn't their job. There's no legal obligation on the part of the police, due to constraints of reality (they can't be everywhere), to provide "protection" to any given individual. 

While in the few cases where police happen upon a crime in progress, or are alerted in time to respond while one's ongoing, they may "protect" someone; they really provide "protection" through general deterrence, which rests on criminals' perception of the probability that -after committing a crime- the police will catch them and they'll be punished by the courts.

To be frank, police exist to protect criminals from their victims. Recall that, at root, the "social contract" involves individuals surrendering their right to seek personal vengeance for harms committed to the state in return for the state providing that service in a dispassionate way. The point is to eliminate blood feuds.

What is not surrendered is the right and responsibility of *self-defense* against crime.

Comment: .

I took the survey.

It was simple, easy to understand and fill out.

It hardly touched on the issue of the ballot - FPTP, Preferred/Ranked Ballot or Proportional Representation.

It read to me as if it was designed to determine general priorities of survey respondents rather than their ballot preferences.

All this criticism from the opposition is just a lot of hot air.

The CPC wants FPTP because they will never be able to pull in the support of a majority of voters with a ranked ballot or PR and will likely see their seat share shrink.

The NDP wants PR because it will likely increase their seat share.

The Liberals want ranked ballot because, where they are not first choice, they will always be second choice and thus gain seats.

None of the options are perfect.

Which is the least imperfect?

Comment: “Families see a real deterioration of their loved ones when they’re ALC."  No question. However, let's not blame ALC. It's a problem even when the individual--like my 93 year old mother-in-law-- is fortunate enough to have very good Long Term Care.

Earlier this week, we picked her up from the home and brought her into our own for the day (no steps to the main floor).  She fell. Again.  Almost preordained.  She feel 8 times  the final year she lived in her own house. No injury this time, but a realization that it is simply too risky for her to be anywhere but the long term care facility. Family will pick her up for Xmas dinner at son's home.  We have our fingers crossed.  So, her opportunities to be "outside" the home are really diminished--after only a few months in LTC. 

Deterioration comes with age. It's that deterioration that diminishes the circle of influence and narrows experience, not necessarily the places they live.  All ALC may do is speed up the inevitable process.
